meta.description: Gravel God Training Guide Content Template

brief.title: 1 路 Training Plan Brief
brief.intro: Welcome to your **{{RACE_NAME}}** training plan. {{RACE_DISTANCE_MILES}} miles with {{RACE_ELEVATION}} feet of climbing. {{RACE_INTRO}}

plan_prepares.title: This Plan Prepares You for All of It
plan_prepares.content: Every workout, long ride, and recovery week is designed around {{RACE_NAME}}'s specific demands. {{RACE_SPECIFIC_PREP}}

subsections.title: Training Methodology Matched to Your Reality
subsections.content:
You're on the **{{TIER}}** tier with **{{TIER_HOURS_MIN}}-{{TIER_HOURS_MAX}}** hours per week. This specific combination determines your optimal training philosophy.

{{TIER_DESCRIPTION}}

before_you_start.title: 2 路 Before You Start
before_you_start.health_warning:
This should go without saying, but we'll say it anyway: training is hard. It puts considerable stress on your cardiovascular system, your musculoskeletal system, and your body's ability to recover and adapt.

Ideally, you should get a physical before starting this plan. Have regular blood work done. Be confident you're healthy enough to handle the training load prescribed here.
before_you_start.cycling_dangerous:
Let's be clear: cycling is dangerous. People die every day riding their bikes. The risk is real. You're accepting that risk by choosing to train and race.

That said, you can manage the risk: Don't take stupid risks. Don't antagonize vehicles. Wear a helmet. Use lights. Ride predictably.

mandatory: Power meter or heart rate monitor

before_you_start.trainingpeaks_setup: Your training plan lives in TrainingPeaks. Once you purchase the plan, it appears in your TrainingPeaks calendar as a series of structured workouts. Each workout includes power/heart rate targets, durations, and descriptions explaining the purpose.

training_fundamentals.title: 3 路 Training Fundamentals

steps.name: Stress
steps.description: You apply training stressa hard workout that exceeds your current capacity. This creates disruption: muscle fibers develop microtears, glycogen stores deplete, metabolic waste accumulates.

steps.name: Fatigue
steps.description: Immediately after training, you're weaker than before you started. This is normal. Fatigue is the signal that triggers adaptation.

steps.name: Recovery
steps.description: Given adequate rest, nutrition, and time, your body initiates repair: muscle fibers rebuild, mitochondria multiply, capillary density increases.

steps.name: Adaptation (Supercompensation)
steps.description: If recovery is complete, your body doesn't just return to baselineit overshoots. You're now stronger than you were before the workout.

steps.name: Apply New Stress
steps.description: Once you've adapted, you apply a slightly larger stress. The cycle repeats. Over weeks and months, these small adaptations compound into meaningful fitness gains.

practical_rules: Training stress must be adequate but not excessive
Recovery must be prioritized as much as training

your_arc.title: 4 路 Your {{PLAN_WEEKS}}-Week Arc
your_arc.intro: Understanding the big picture helps you navigate the individual weeks.

training_zones.title: 5 路 Training Zones
training_zones.intro: Zones exist to quantify intensity and give you a common language for prescribing workouts. But here's the paradox: **the end goal of measuring intensity is to help you develop a feeling for intensity.**

measurement_systems.power: Most precise system. Measures actual work output in watts. Immediate feedback. This is the gold standard.
measurement_systems.heart_rate: Secondary system. Lags behind power by 1-3 minutes. Still useful, especially for pacing long efforts.
measurement_systems.rpe: Subjective. Your body's experience of the effort. Not precise. Always available. Sometimes more important than devices.

zone_table.name: Active Recovery
zone_table.feel: Very easy, relaxed pace. Full conversation possible.

zone_table.name: Endurance
zone_table.feel: All-day pace. This is where you spend MOST of your training time.

zone_table.name: Tempo
zone_table.feel: Comfortably hard. Talking in short sentences.

zone_table.name: Gravel Race Pace
zone_table.feel: Uncomfortably sustainable. Hard enough to hurt, easy enough to repeat.

zone_table.name: Lactate Threshold
zone_table.feel: Hard, controlled effort. Can only say a few words.

zone_table.name: VO2max
zone_table.feel: Very hard, heavy breathing. Near maximum.

zone_table.name: Anaerobic
zone_table.feel: All-out efforts, 30 seconds to 3 minutes max.

critical_notes: Zones are descriptive, not prescriptiveyou're targeting a range, not a precise number
Easy means easymost people train too hard on easy days
RPE is the ultimate arbiterwhen devices and body conflict, trust your body
FTP changes slowlydon't retest every week

universal_rules.title: Warm Up Properly
universal_rules.content: For intensity sessions: 15-20 minutes Z1Z2Z3. Include 31 min at Z3-Z4 to 'open the legs'.

universal_rules.title: Do the Actual Workout
universal_rules.content: Execute what's prescribed. Not more. Not less. Trust the plan.

universal_rules.title: Chase Time-in-Zone, Not Hero Intervals
universal_rules.content: The goal is highest average power across the entire set, not crushing the first interval then dying.

universal_rules.title: Stop If Power Drops >10%
universal_rules.content: Quality beats quantity. Four quality intervals at 300W beats six degraded intervals averaging 270W.

common_mistakes: Drifting into Z3 because you're bored
Riding with faster friends and getting pulled up
z2.fix: Discipline. Easy means easy. This is 70-80% of your training volume. Protect it.

gspot.fix: This is intentional race-pace work, not your default easy ride.

threshold.target: 95-100% FTP, RPE 7-8, very hard but controlled
common_mistakes: Treating it like an FTP test
threshold.fix: Conservative start, controlled execution, complete the work.

fueling_hydration.title: 8 路 Fueling & Hydration
fueling_hydration.intro: You can have perfect training, a dialed bike, and excellent pacing strategy. None of it matters if you run out of fuel halfway through your race.

daily_nutrition.carbs: 3-7g per kg bodyweight (depends on training volume)

race_day_fueling.pre_race: 2-3g carbs per kg bodyweight, 3-4 hours before start
race_day_fueling.during: Start fueling at 30 minutes. 70-80g carbs per hour. Set a timer.
race_day_fueling.when_stomach_rebels: Back off intensity for 5-10 minutes. Switch to liquid calories. Small sips, not big gulps.

mental_training.title: 9 路 Mental Training
mental_training.intro: Physical training builds the engine. Mental training determines whether you use that engine when things get hard.

techniques.name: 6-2-7 Breathing
techniques.description: Inhale 6 seconds, hold 2 seconds, exhale 7 seconds. The key is that the exhale is longer than the inhalethis triggers the calming response.
techniques.when_to_use: Pre-race anxiety, mid-race panic, after a bad section

examples: This is supposed to be hard
Pain is temporary, quitting is permanent
Just get to the next aid station

techniques.name: Personal Highlight Reel
scenes: Past moment of strengtha specific time when you overcame something difficult
Future crucial moment in this racesee yourself executing perfectly
Crossing the finish linein full sensory detail

race_tactics.title: 10 路 Race Tactics for {{RACE_NAME}}
race_tactics.intro: Every long gravel race follows a predictable three-act structure. Understanding this structure lets you make smart decisions when others are making emotional ones.

three_acts.description: The first 60-90 minutes is chaos. Fresh legs meet nervous energy. Attacks fly. Groups form, then shatter.
three_acts.your_job: Survive. Don't try to win the race in the first hour. Find a sustainable group. Eat. Drink. Let others burn matches.

three_acts.description: Order returns. Groups stabilize. The race can start to feel manageable, even easy.
three_acts.your_job: Stay disciplined about nutrition and hydration. Contribute to pace line but don't take hero pulls. Save energy.

three_acts.description: The bill comes due. Under-fueled riders bonk. Under-prepared riders cramp. Mentally weak riders check out.
three_acts.your_job: If you've done the work, this is where you move up. Maintain your pace while others lose theirs.

flat_tire: If hole visible, insert plug immediately
Resume at Z2 for 2-3 minutes to settle back in
dropped_from_group: Assess honestly: were you overextended or did they surge?
Look for riders at similar pace
If solo, accept itfocus on YOUR race

race_week.title: 12 路 Race Week Protocol
race_week.intro: By race week, the training is done. You can't add fitness in the final seven daysyou can only preserve what you've built or add dumb fatigue through poor decisions.

race_morning_timeline.action: Wake up. Eat familiar, high-carb, low-fiber breakfast. Target 1-2g carbs per kg.
Arrive at venue. Set up bike and gear. Use the bathroom. Begin sipping fluids.
Final bike check. Short warm-up spin. Start pre-race nutrition (100-200 cal carbs).
Run through highlight reel visualization. Review performance statements.
6-2-7 breathing. Find your spot. Check nutrition is accessible.
Controlled effort. Find sustainable rhythm. First gel at 20 minutes.

your_weekly_schedule.title: Your Personal Weekly Schedule
your_weekly_schedule.intro: This is YOUR schedule based on your availability and preferences:
priority_order: Key cycling sessions ( days)These drive fitness gains
Easy ridesRecovery, can be shortened or skipped

strength_training.title: Your Strength Program
strength_training.intro: Your plan includes **{{STRENGTH_FREQUENCY}}x/week** strength sessions that are coordinated with your cycling to prevent interference and maximize adaptation.

exercise_modifications.intro: Based on your profile, these exercises have been excluded:
exercise_modifications.note: Substitute exercises are provided in your workouts.

equipment.intro: Your workouts are designed for your available equipment:

execution_tips: Watch the video demos before each exercise
Warm up: 5 minutes easy cardio + activation exercises
Follow the prescribed orderexercises are sequenced intentionally
Use the rest periodsstrength needs recovery between sets
Log your weightstrack what you lift so you can progress
Stop before failureleave 1-2 reps in the tank

importing_workouts.title: Importing Workouts to TrainingPeaks
steps: Click **+ Add Workout** on the appropriate day
Choose the ZWO file for that week/session
The workout will appear with full instructions and video links

explanation: Phase = Learn to Lift, Lift Heavy Sh*t, Lift Fast, Don't Lose It

missed_workouts.title: What If I Miss a Workout?

strength.same_week: Move to next available day (avoid day before key cycling)
strength.already_past: Skip it. Don't double up. Move on to next week's session.
strength.multiple_weeks: Just pick up where you are in the plan. Don't try to catch up.

cycling.same_week: Try to fit it in, even shortened
cycling.already_past: Note it happened, don't try to make it up
cycling.multiple: Consider if something needs to change (schedule, life, etc.)

questions.q: What if I miss a week of training?
questions.a: One week won't kill you. Jump back in where the plan currently isdon't try to 'make up' missed work. Forward progress only.

questions.q: Can I do this plan entirely indoors?
questions.a: Technically yes, but you're missing critical skills development. Do at least 30-40% of your volume outside, especially long rides.

questions.q: What if my FTP changes mid-plan?
questions.a: Test again at Week 6-7 if curious, but only adjust zones if FTP changed by 5+ watts. Small fluctuations are noise.

questions.q: How do I know if I'm overtraining?
questions.a: Elevated resting heart rate, persistent fatigue, declining performance, irritability, poor sleep. If hitting 3+ symptoms, take 2-3 days off.

questions.q: What if I can't hit the prescribed watts?
questions.a: Either your FTP is set too high, or you're under-recovered. Take an extra rest day, retest FTP if needed.

closing.title: Let's Go
closing.content:
You have the plan.

You understand how training works, how to execute the workouts, how to fuel and hydrate, how to manage your mental game, and how to approach race day.

Now do the work.

Not perfectly. Not heroically.

Consistently. Intelligently. Over {{PLAN_WEEKS}} weeks.

Show up for the workouts. Do them correctly. Recover properly. Trust the process.

On race morning, you'll stand at the start line knowing you did everything you could to prepare. That confidencenot hope, not optimism, but confidence based on completed workis what this plan builds.

**Let's get after it, {{ATHLETE_FIRST_NAME}}.**

unbound_gravel_200.name: Unbound Gravel 200
unbound_gravel_200.intro: This isn't a race you survive by accident. It's a race you prepare foror it prepares you for a very long day.
unbound_gravel_200.course_description: The Unbound Gravel 200 covers 200 miles with 11,000 feet of cumulative elevation gain through the Flint Hills of Kansas. Climate is the silent killerhot. The race is well-supported with aid stations.
unbound_gravel_200.demands: Base fitness alone won't cut ityou need specific preparation for sustained output. Heat acclimatization isn't optional. Endurance pacing is criticalsmooth power wins over surges.
unbound_gravel_200.specific_prep: Heat adaptation protocols. Endurance pacing for race distance. Technical handling for flint rock. Mental training for when it all falls apart.
unbound_gravel_200.weather_notes: Hot and humid, 85-95掳F. Heat management is critical. Start hydrated. Pre-cool if possible. Sun protection is mandatory.
unbound_gravel_200.tactics: Start conservatively. Fuel early and often. Be patient on climbs. The wind after mile 100 is realsave matches for it.
non_negotiables: Heat adaptation protocol built into weeks 6-10
Flint-specific cornering and line selection skills

mental_landmarks.name: The Honeymoon
mental_landmarks.description: Everything feels easy. HUGE temptation to go hard. DON'T.

mental_landmarks.name: Where the Field Shatters
mental_landmarks.description: The rollers blow apart groups. Stay disciplined. DO NOT chase.

mental_landmarks.name: The Dark Patch
mental_landmarks.description: Where motivation dies. This is EXPECTED. Keep. Moving. Forward.

mental_landmarks.name: Second Wind
mental_landmarks.description: Energy returns like magic. Capitalize on this window.

mental_landmarks.name: Late-Race Relief
mental_landmarks.description: Light at end of tunnel. Push throughyou've earned this.

default.name: Gravel Race
default.intro: This race will test your fitness, your fueling, and your mental resilience.
default.course_description: A challenging gravel course that will require sustained effort and smart pacing.
default.demands: Endurance, pacing discipline, and the ability to fuel properly for hours.
default.specific_prep: Long rides building toward race duration. Race-pace practice. Equipment testing.
default.weather_notes: Check forecast 5 days out and adjust gear accordingly.
default.tactics: Start conservative. Fuel early. Don't chase attacks you can't sustain.

ayahuasca.description: At **4-8 hours per week**, you're in the AYAHUASCA tier. This is survival modejust enough training to finish the race without embarrassing yourself. Not enough to compete. Every session counts because you don't have extras.
ayahuasca.expectations: With 4-8 hours per week, you're building base fitness. Realistic expectations: You'll finish. You won't be fast. Focus on completion, not competition.

finisher.description: At **8-12 hours per week**, you're in the FINISHER tier. You're training to complete the race comfortably, with some speed. Two quality sessions per week, supplemented by endurance work.
finisher.expectations: With 8-12 hours per week, you're building solid fitness. Realistic expectations: You'll finish strong. Middle of the pack is realistic. Top third possible with perfect execution.

compete.description: At **12-18 hours per week**, you're in the COMPETE tier. You're training to race properly. Not just participatecompete. Three to four quality sessions per week, multiple endurance rides, and long rides that hit 5-6 hours with race-specific intensity.
compete.expectations: With 12-18 hours per week, you're building race fitness. Realistic expectations: This volume typically places riders in the top third of the field. You're training to compete, not just participate.

podium.description: At **18-25 hours per week**, you're in the PODIUM tier. You're training for a result. Four to five quality sessions, double days, and weekend epics. This is professional-level commitment for amateur racers.
podium.expectations: With 18-25 hours per week, you're building elite amateur fitness. Realistic expectations: Top 10% of field. Podium in your age group is realistic. Results depend on execution.

learn_to_lift.name: Learn to Lift
tips: Focus on perfect form over weight
Watch the video demos before each exercise
If something doesn't feel right, regress to an easier variation
You should feel challenged but not crushed

lift_heavy_shit.name: Lift Heavy Sh*t
tips: Progressive overload: add weight when you can complete all reps with good form
If form breaks down, reduce weight
This phase builds the strength foundation for power later
Expect some delayed onset muscle soreness (DOMS)

lift_fast.name: Lift Fast
lift_fast.reps: Lower reps (3-6) with focus on SPEED
tips: Move the weight as fast as possible with control
If you can't move it fast, reduce the weight
This phase converts your strength into cycling power

dont_lose_it.name: Don't Lose It
tips: Just enough stimulus to maintain, not build
You should feel refreshed after these sessions
This preserves your strength while prioritizing cycling freshness
Never feel crushed going into race week
